title: Arbitrary file overwrites in `node-tar`

profile.name: Node.js third-party modules
profile.about: This program is used to handle vulnerabilities in the Node.js ecosystem.

vulnerability_information:
# Background

I was looking for vulnerabilities in a different tar library, `tar-fs`, and discovered a bug that allowed me to overwrite arbitrary files on the host system using its default extraction method. After reporting the bug to the maintainer of `tar-fs`, Mathias Buus, he realized that `node-tar` was vulnerable to the same attack. However, he found that the npm client is not vulnerable here since the library it uses, `pacote`, [doesn't allow any hardlinks or symlinks](https://github.com/zkat/pacote/blob/latest/lib/extract-stream.js#L41).

# Vulnerability

If a tar file contains a hardlink to an existing file on the filesystem, and then a subsequent regular file with the same name as this hardlink, the contents of the regular file will overwrite the contents of the original file.

For example, the attached file, `hardlink_exploit.tar.gz`, contains two relevant files. First, a hardlink to `/tmp/overwriteme` called `hardboi/yyy`, and second, a regular file called `hardboi/yyy` containing `oops`.

To demonstrate this vulnerability:

- Make a file called `/tmp/overwriteme` with whatever contents
- Extract the attached tar archive using the following code:

```
tar = require('tar')

tar.x(
  {
    file: 'hardlink_exploit.tar.gz'
  }
).then(_=> { console.log("done") })
```

- Observe the contents of /tmp/overwriteme are now "oops"

I'm not sure what the best way to resolve this vulnerability is. My local copy of GNU Tar isn't vulnerable because by default it doesn't allow hardlinks that point to an absolute file or that try to directory traverse above the parent:

```
$ tar -xvf hardlink_pkg.tar.gz
hardboi/
tar: Removing leading `/' from hard link targets
hardboi/yyy
tar: hardboi/yyy: Cannot hard link to ‘tmp/overwriteme’: No such file or directory
hardboi/yyy
hardboi/package.json
tar: Exiting with failure status due to previous errors
```

## Impact

Applications, of which there are probably many, that rely on `node-tar` to be secure-by-default when extracting a tar file are in fact vulnerable. Unless hardlinks are explicitly disabled as in `pacote`, arbitrary files can be overwritten with the permissions of the user running `node-tar`.
vulnerability_information_html:
Background

I was looking for vulnerabilities in a different tar library, tar-fs, and discovered a bug that allowed me to overwrite arbitrary files on the host system using its default extraction method. After reporting the bug to the maintainer of tar-fs, Mathias Buus, he realized that node-tar was vulnerable to the same attack. However, he found that the npm client is not vulnerable here since the library it uses, pacote, doesn't allow any hardlinks or symlinks.

Vulnerability

If a tar file contains a hardlink to an existing file on the filesystem, and then a subsequent regular file with the same name as this hardlink, the contents of the regular file will overwrite the contents of the original file.

For example, the attached file, hardlink_exploit.tar.gz, contains two relevant files. First, a hardlink to /tmp/overwriteme called hardboi/yyy, and second, a regular file called hardboi/yyy containing oops.

To demonstrate this vulnerability:

  • Make a file called /tmp/overwriteme with whatever contents
  • Extract the attached tar archive using the following code:
tar = require('tar')

tar.x(
  {
    file: 'hardlink_exploit.tar.gz'
  }
).then(_=> { console.log("done") })
  • Observe the contents of /tmp/overwriteme are now "oops"

I'm not sure what the best way to resolve this vulnerability is. My local copy of GNU Tar isn't vulnerable because by default it doesn't allow hardlinks that point to an absolute file or that try to directory traverse above the parent:

$ tar -xvf hardlink_pkg.tar.gz
hardboi/
tar: Removing leading `/' from hard link targets
hardboi/yyy
tar: hardboi/yyy: Cannot hard link to ‘tmp/overwriteme’: No such file or directory
hardboi/yyy
hardboi/package.json
tar: Exiting with failure status due to previous errors

Impact

Applications, of which there are probably many, that rely on node-tar to be secure-by-default when extracting a tar file are in fact vulnerable. Unless hardlinks are explicitly disabled as in pacote, arbitrary files can be overwritten with the permissions of the user running node-tar.

activities.message: Looking over https://www.npmjs.com/browse/depended/tar ... this seems potentially pretty bad
activities.markdown_message: Looking over https://www.npmjs.com/browse/depended/tar ... this seems potentially pretty bad

activities.message: @max thanks for reporting this. So the maintainer is already aware of this. Is this fixed already? We usually invite maintainer in reports to discuss the issue with them. If Mathias wishes it, just give me his email address :)
activities.markdown_message: @max thanks for reporting this. So the maintainer is already aware of this. Is this fixed already? We usually invite maintainer in reports to discuss the issue with them. If Mathias wishes it, just give me his email address :)

activities.message:
`tar-fs` and now `node-tar` are [both](https://github.com/mafintosh/tar-fs/commit/06672828e6fa29ac8551b1b6f36c852a9a3c58a2) [patched](https://github.com/npm/node-tar/commit/b0c58433c22f5e7fe8b1c76373f27e3f81dcd4c8) now, yes. `node-tar` was not fixed when I made the original report.

Mathias's email address is mathiasbuus@gmail.com
activities.markdown_message:
tar-fs and now node-tar are both patched now, yes. node-tar was not fixed when I made the original report.

Mathias's email address is mathiasbuus@gmail.com

activities.message: I should add that there is a popular web service that is vulnerable to this attack, so please hold off on making this report public until that's fixed! I'll post a comment here when that happens.
activities.markdown_message: I should add that there is a popular web service that is vulnerable to this attack, so please hold off on making this report public until that's fixed! I'll post a comment here when that happens.

activities.message: Alright, popular web service has been fixed!
activities.markdown_message: Alright, popular web service has been fixed!

activities.message: I think it should be OK to close this report now, since everything is fixed! I'm reaching out to the `node-tar` and `unpkg` maintainers right now to make sure it's cool for me to make a blog post about this.
activities.markdown_message: I think it should be OK to close this report now, since everything is fixed! I'm reaching out to the node-tar and unpkg maintainers right now to make sure it's cool for me to make a blog post about this.

activities.message: @max any progress on this? can we publicize?
activities.markdown_message: @max any progress on this? can we publicize?

activities.message: Yeah, everything has been patched for ages!
activities.markdown_message: Yeah, everything has been patched for ages!
